description: English pre- +‎ curse, from Latin praecursum (supine of praecurrō [“run before”]).

examples: And even the like precurse of fierce events,As harbingers preceding still the fatesAnd prologue to the omen coming on,Have heaven and earth together demonstratedUnto our climatures and countrymen. (Shakespeare)

verbs.description: precurse (third-person singular simple present precurses, present participle precursing, simple past and past participle precursed)

examples: It is true that competition in capitalism precurses new economic order.
